pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces prop-valued mixins for vector addition operations that preserve or reflect order, and provides instances relating it to ordered commutative monoids and to covariant/contravariant classes.  In a future PR, we expect to use this to generalize Hahn module structures, for example giving an `R((z))`-module structure to `z^s V((z))` for `V` an `R`-module.

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Thank you for letting me know.  I will rewrite the classes as prop-valued mixins.

### Import summary

No significant changes to the import graph

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Sorry I am going to tank your dreams but please do not follow one-type typeclasses (eg `OrderedAddMonoid`) when writing two-type typeclasses (eg `OrderedVAdd`). The reason is that the number of algebraic order interactions is already pretty high on a single type `α`, so it becomes unbearable when you add a second type `β` (and you can guess since you didn't define `OrderedAddTorsor`, which is the object you're supposedly interested in).

Instead, we handle that using prop-valued mixins. Here, it would be akin to `PosSMulMono`.

Final note: People do care about multiplicative torsors sometimes, so it would be nice if you wrote all the theory multiplicatively and used `to_additive` to get back what you wanted in the first place.

It would be nice to have this multiplicativized at some point. But let's move forward with this for now.

bors merge

The first group of caps gets lowercased

```suggestion
theorem vadd_lt_vadd_of_le_of_lt [LE G] [Preorder P] [OrderedCancelVAdd G P]
```
and elsewhere

The reason is that the number of algebraic order interactions is already pretty high on a single type `α`, so it becomes unbearable when you add a second type `β` (and you can guess since you didn't define `OrderedAddTorsor`, which is the object you're supposedly interested in).

Final note: People do care about multiplicative torsors sometimes, so it would be nice if you wrote all the theory multiplicatively and used `to_additive` to get back what you wanted in the first place.
